awd_titl_txt: RTML: Small: Design of System Software to Facilitate Real-Time Neuromorphic Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
Machine learning methods such as neural networks have been successfully used in real-time computer vision and signal processing areas. Neuromorphic systems, which mimic biological neurons and synapses, can be used to implement these neural networks in energy-constrained computing platforms. However, due to the absence of a user-friendly programming interface, the use of neuromorphic systems is currently limited to research. This project will develop such an interface, allowing for these systems to be more easily programmed and used by the broader science and engineering community within the U.S. The project will integrate undergraduate education within multidisciplinary graduate research, with students at all levels and across different disciplines participating in the proposed research activities. High school girls will participate in workshops during the summer, learning how to program robots equipped with neuromorphic hardware. The open-sourced programming tools will enable faster development and commercialization of neuromorphic systems in the U.S. and facilitate collaboration with other such communities worldwide.

Executing a program on a computer involves several steps: compilation, resource allocation, and run-time mapping. Although very well defined for mainstream computers, no prior work has investigated these steps in a systematic manner for neuromorphic systems. This project will develop compiler tool chains to translate a user's machine learning program to low-level languages that can be interpreted by neuromorphic systems. A key initiative is to develop a common representation across different platforms. Resource optimization strategies will be developed to improve program performance; as well as an Operating System like framework that will allow programmers to easily deploy their machine learning programs on neuromorphic systems. The technical contributions will be demonstrated using two case studies: real-time sleep apnea detection and real-time image segmentation from video.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Neuromorphic systems are an emerging form of computing systems implementing biological neurons and synapses in hardware. Despite the significant technological advances made on the hardware front, the software stacks for these systems have remained largely unexplored. Today's neuromorphic systems require a significant labor-intensive and time-consuming manual programming by system administrators to admit and execute scientific computations on these systems. As these systems continue to become mainstream, their complex interfaces will be a critical bottleneck for engineers. Therefore, there remains a pressing need to improve the programmability of these new forms of computing system through architecting their hardware-software interface. To this end, we made the following key contributions.

First, given the ubiquity of Python and its perpetually increasing integration into K-12 education, we developed an open-source Python framework called PyCARL to interface with CARLsim a simulator developed at University of California, Irvine and now used to simulate biology-inspired machine learning algorithms. Using this framework, researchers can study the detailed behavior of neurons and synapses. This will facilitate developing a deeper understanding of machine learning models and fine-tune them to improve performance.

Second, we develop an operating system like framework where machine learning models can be allocated to the hardware to improve real-time performance. The proposed framework can help designers to perform architectural exploration early in the design stage and therefore, it can significantly improve time-to-market of neuromorphic products.

Third, we develop an algorithm to train machine learning models that can be implemented efficiently on a neuromorphic system.

 The mapping framework developed in this project period will enable real-time execution of machine learning applications on neuromorphic hardware. This is a significant enabler of the two demonstration components of the project - sleep classification for health analytics and video segmentation for autonomous vehicles.

On the healthcare front, the project will develop real-time and automatic sleep state classification. Obstructive sleep apnea, when a person stops breathing for periods during sleep, is a serious sleep disorder. Patients with sleep apnea have a greater risk of abnormal heartbeat, heart attack, stroke, and recent studies have shown an association between sleep apnea and problems like cancer and type-2 diabetes, as well as shortened lifespan. Sleep staging or classification is a necessary first step to diagnose sleep apnea in a hospital sleep-study setting; as well as to provide positional feedback (haptic or vibro-tactile) in real time to make the user adjust her/his sleeping position. By enabling this classification on low-power neuromorphic platforms, the proposed research will make a significant contribution towards sleep apnea detection in home settings.

On the autonomous vehicle front, an autonomous vehicle is expected to parse the scene it perceives using an artificial eye (camera) and navigate autonomously or make intelligent decisions. A key step to achieve such automation is segmenting the image in real-time. Image segmentation is the process of partitioning a digital image into multiple segments such that a segment of the image is uniform and homogeneous with respect to some characteristic such as gray tone or texture. Adjacent segments should have significantly different values with respect to the characteristic on which they are uniform. Boundaries of each segment should be simple, not ragged, and must be spatially accurate.  The problem of image segmentation remains one of the greatest challenges for computer vision and is key to many other domains such as medical image processing and security. Real-time image segmentation on neuromorphic platforms can help to achieve autonomous navigations.

Overall, all project goals were successfully achieved in this project duration, resulting in 20 conference and journal publications. All frameworks developed under this project are made available to the community as open-source software in order to foster future research in neuromorphic computing. The project employed two undergraduate REU students, and several undergraduate and graduate students. Experiences gathered in this project have enabled them to secure internships and employment at the nation’s top software and hardware firms.
